title: Font ID; it looks like a revival of Thermo by ATF
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804042255im_/http:/typophile.com/files/ThermoRevival_4417.jpg)

Hello. I'm trying to find this font, it looks like a revival of Thermo from ATF. Until I saw this, I didn't think there was a digital version. As you can see, I am only 5 letters shy of a complete uppercase. (Missing J, Q, V, X, Z.)

I found this, but the rough edges don't work for me.  
 [http://www.archivetype.com/Latest/Archive-Thermo-Announcement.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804042255/http:/www.archivetype.com/Latest/Archive-Thermo-Announcement.html "http://www.archivetype.com/Latest/Archive-Thermo-Announcement.html")

The attached letters come from a piece of art, so there is a possibility that the artist custom-created them. (The artist is unavailable to ask directly.) I'm hoping htere is a commercial font out there.

Thanks in advance for your help!

~Sean
author: Cranialtorque

comments.content:
That K is different than in the Thermotype shown in Mac McGrew's book. So is the C, G, and the M and N. Are you sure this is ATF Thermotype? If this is an 'interpretation' then they took a lot of liberties with the original.

A similar font that does exist in digital form is [Hollywood Deco](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804042255/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/spiecegraphics/hollywood-deco-sg/) (also an ATF typeface, from 1932, a year after Thermotype).

- Mike Yanega

I'm not sure of anything, actually. The one other bit of info I have points to this font possibly being named "Thermo 300". The designer working with the file that has these letters outlined says Illustrator asks for "Thermo 300" every time she opens it.

Thanks for the Hollywood Deco link, it is close but not quite it.
